name: Sweden
partner: Central European Institute of Asian Studies (CEIAS)
takeaway: The Swedish economy has significant exposure to China in terms of trade and investments. Notably, Sweden’s largest private employer, Volvo Cars, is a Chinese-owned company. Swedish universities have also been engaged in various forms of cooperation with China for many years. However, in recent years, the technology sector’s exposure has decreased in some areas, as evidenced by the decision to limit Chinese involvement in the 5G rollout.

Public opinion in Sweden has become increasingly negative towards China, as reflected in several recent surveys. The Swedish media is generally critical of the Chinese government, and no established political parties, opinion leaders, or think tanks support it. At the local level, there has been widespread disengagement from cooperation with China, a trend more pronounced in Sweden than in any other European country.

China's influence in Sweden’s military and law enforcement spheres is minimal. In terms of foreign policy, the Swedish government supports a unified EU approach to China and strong transatlantic ties. At the same time, it seeks a pragmatic and stable bilateral relationship with Beijing.
description-1: In 2023, Sweden had a GDP per capita of US$56,305 and a total population of 10.52 million people.
description-2: Sweden established full diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China in 1950. Sweden was ranked 3rd in Reporters Without Borders‘ 2024 World Press Freedom Index, and rated Free in Freedom House‘s 2024 Global Freedom Index, with a score of 99/100.

Media.note: This indicator measures whether local media outlets broadcast news, video clips, or other contents provided by PRC state-fund media. The phenomenon can be observed via footages of content pieces. Therefore, press statement from PRC governmental agencies do not fall into the caterory of contents provided by PRC state-fund media.
